channel.title: Law News@Emory
channel.description: All the latest news from Emory University.

item.title: Future of Libya: Emory Experts Available
item.description: Emory University has faculty experts available to discuss the situation in Libya, the death of Moammar Gadhafi, and what the future of the country and transitional government may be.y

item.title: 2011 Emory Medalists Honored for Dedication to the Greater Good
item.description: Two of Emory University's most distinguished and dedicated graduates will receive one of the university's highest honors, the Emory Medal, Thursday, Oct. 6 in a special ceremony on campus.

item.title: Jewish Law Supports Reproductive Technologies, Says Emory Professor
item.description: Jewish law supports current and emerging forms of biotechnology used in assisted reproduction - including artificial insemination, surrogacy, embryo screening and even more debatable techniques - as long as the overriding intent is to "produce a healthy or healthier child," says Rabbi Michael J. Broyde, professor of law at Emory University.

item.title: Child Law, Advocacy to be Focus of Emory Conference
item.description: "Child Law: Past, Present and Future," is the topic for the eighth annual Emory Public Interest Committee (EPIC) conference, Saturday, Oct. 1, which will bring together pediatricians, educators, attorneys, legislators and professors to discuss children¿s rights and vulnerabilities in the courts and under the law.

item.title: Emory Law's Turner Environmental Law Clinic Receives $40,000 Grant
item.description: The Turner Environmental Law Clinic has received a $40,000 Turner Foundation grant to support the clinic's pro bono work and programs that provide real-world experience to student attorneys.

item.title: Emory Law Graduates Receive Prestigious Public Interest Fellowships
item.description: Five Emory University School of Law class of 2011 graduates begin work this month at public interest fellowships with programs that emphasize medical and educational justice for indigent and vulnerable clients.

item.title: International Law Expert Delivers Inaugural Bederman Lecture Sept. 26
item.description: Professor David J. Bederman will deliver the inaugural David J. Bederman Lecture, "Public Law and Custom," at 4 p.m. Monday, Sept. 26, at Emory University School of Law, 1301 Clifton Rd.

item.title: 9/11 Expert: U.S. Foreign Policy, Muslim Attitudes Toward the U.S.
item.description: Law professor Abdullahi An-Na'im is an expert in Islam, Human Rights and Shari'a. An-Na'im discusses how U.S. foreign policy changed in the wake of 9/11 and how Muslim peoples around the world feel about the U.S.

item.title: 9/11 Expert: American Tolerance of Muslims
item.description: Vincent Cornell, professor of Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies, is an expert in contemporary islamic reform, extremism, Islam and the West, Muslim-Christian relations and stereotypes. Cornell discusses whether Americans are more or less tolerant of Muslims since 9/11 and how the world can get past Islamophobia.

item.title: 9/11 Expert: Jewish Perspectives
item.description: Emory Law professor Michael Broyde is an expert in Jewish law and ethics, comparative religious law and editor of the new book, "Contending with Catastrophe: Jewish Perspectives on September 11th."

item.title: Experts on Post-9/11 Issues Available
item.description: Emory University experts in Islam, human rights, Muslims in America, law, ethics and terrorism are available to discuss the long-term effects of 9/11 as the world marks the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks.

item.title: Glendon to Speak on Universal Access to Religious Freedom
item.description: Mary Ann Glendon, Learned Hand Professor of Law at Harvard University and former U.S. Ambassador to the Vatican, will speak about the challenges of the universal right to religious freedom in a world of diversity at 7:30 p.m. Sept. 20 at Emory University School of Law.

item.title: From 'Chaos,' a Budget Deal is Emerging, says Emory Congressional Expert
item.description: The Gang of Six plan demonstrates "the capacity of the American Constitutional system to continue to generate serious proposals to address the complex and politically contentious budget and debt ceiling issues -- even after negotiations led by the president had reached an impasse," says Emory University political scientist Randall Strahan, a Congressional politics expert.

item.title: Supreme Court Continues Strong Protection of Free Speech in Recent Ruling, Says Law Expert
item.description: The United States Supreme Court struck down a California law that penalized selling or renting violent video games to minors without a parent's consent, ruling the law violated the Free Speech Clause of the First Amendment. The decision came on the final day of the term and the result was not unexpected, says Emory University law professor and First Amendment expert Julie Seaman, who specializes in issues involving hate speech.

item.title: Land Banks Key Tool in Foreclosure Crisis, Says Housing Expert
item.description: Empty lots and unoccupied buildings hold the potential for fueling economic recovery, driving community development and strengthening real estate markets, says housing law expert Frank Alexander.
